author: Miranda Larbi
title: Everyone’s losing it over the fact that you can buy a chocolate orange and lettuce sandwich in Wales
text:
(Picture: Twitter/Delusions of grandad) Every kid dreams of the day when they can make their own lunchtime sandwiches and fill them with whatever crap they like.
Crisp sarnies. Marshmellow baps. Chocolate rolls.
As you grow older, however, you start to conform to the idea sandwich fillings are almost exclusively reserved for salads, cheese and meat.
Pizza Express are now doing a three-course vegan menu Unless that is, you live in Cardiff.
One Twitter user recently came across a couple of sandwiches being sold that would send even the most sugar-addicted kid into freefall.
@SirSandGoblin tweeted pictures of a liquorice allsorts roll (£1.99 reduced to £0.99) and – even more bizarrely – a chocolate orange and lettuce (no butter) baguette (£2.25).
‘This is now a thing in Cardiff. Yet some people claim Wales is ready for independence,’ he wrote.
This is now a thing in Cardiff. Yet some people claim Wales is ready for independence. pic.twitter.com/pJYdXZYgFB 
— Delusions of grandad (@SirSandGoblin) March 20, 2017 

We wanted to know where exactly these monstrosities were being sold (although we agreed with the ‘no butter’ ruling).
We felt it was in the public interest to track down whoever was abusing Terry’s chocolate orange like this.
But alas, @SirSandGoblin had received sound legal advice preventing him from disclosing his valuable information.
@MirandaLarbi I have been advised by my lawyers not to talk to the metro
— Delusions of grandad (@SirSandGoblin) March 21, 2017 

Which somehow detracted everyone from our pressing quest for answers.
@SirSandGoblin lol. Oh @MirandaLarbi I think you're in need of this https://t.co/aZFEtBbTCC 
— Matt Kilcoyne (@MRJKilcoyne) March 21, 2017 

But where we failed, Medium succeeded.
The baguettes are being sold at Channings Newsagents, Longross Court as a way of ‘adding a bit of fun to the shelves’.
And these sarnies aren’t the first of their kind that they’ve sold – previously they’ve been known to sell ‘Marmite and jelly beans’ baguettes.
The UK waits with bated breath to see what new creation owner Phil comes out with next.
